hero.label: Field Note
hero.title: First Impressions in the Lobby
hero.intro: The lobby scene is our strongest tool for communicating a small office's character in the first minute. This article explains the narrative we build and the priorities we focus on when defining the space.

route.heading: Clarifying the visitor route
route.paragraph1: In our initial plan diagram we briefly describe the steps from entry to meeting area. A clear path between the door, reception, and lounge helps clients imagine the flow.
route.paragraph2: We keep to three core points: the atmosphere at the entrance, the seating layout in the lounge, and how light shifts on the way to the meeting room. Together they answer the first questions about the lobby and set the stage for the rest of the session.

light.heading: Balancing light and material
light.paragraph1: Light is the first visual cue in our lobby narrative. We prepare separate schemes for day and evening scenarios—one section highlighting daylight levels and another collage showing how adjustable fixtures spread through the space.
light.paragraph2: The material palette reinforces the emotion we want the light to convey. Matte surfaces soften it, while brass or copper details sharpen the focal points. Limiting the palette to three main tones keeps the story clear.

structure.heading: Structuring the presentation
structure.paragraph1: We break the lobby story into short steps instead of covering everything at once. The first page sets the mood with a wide angle, the second narrates the user experience, and the third summarises materials and lighting.
structure.paragraph2: We close with a finished view and checklist covering lighting setup, wayfinding graphics, and furniture placement. Everyone leaves the meeting with the same understanding of order and expected atmosphere.

hero.label: Guide
hero.title: How to Tell a Scene Without Text
hero.intro: It is possible to design the empty pages in a presentation without adding copy. This guide summarises how we strengthen the story using visual cues instead of words.

atmosphere.heading: Building atmosphere without words
atmosphere.paragraph1: Before we start, we decide which feeling the space should deliver. Light direction, palette, and materials form the base. Rather than a wide angle, we use three frames to steer the viewer's eye.
atmosphere.paragraph2: Each frame focuses on one element—the floor texture, seating, or the light slipping along the façade—so the audience grasps the whole scene without reading text.

story.heading: Shaping the user story
story.paragraph1: We switch to a timeline approach to build a story without copy. Morning, midday, and evening scenarios show how the space is used throughout the day.
story.paragraph2: Small icons or notes tied to the user's needs support the visuals. Keeping the design minimal—one highlight per frame—prevents overload.

collage.heading: Finishing with a collage
collage.paragraph1: We conclude the scene with a collage placed over a plan or section. Thin lines and short labels indicate light directions, furniture placement, and colour intensity.
collage.paragraph2: The visual approach invites quick feedback during meetings and reveals which parts need refinement without adding text.

hero.label: Workshop Recap
hero.title: In-Studio Concept Sessions
hero.intro: Our weekly concept sessions keep presentation files consistent and moving quickly. This article explains how we plan them, the outputs we expect, and how we share responsibilities.

schedule.heading: Session flow
schedule.paragraph1: Each meeting is structured in 45-minute blocks. One person presents the latest deck while the others listen and note questions.
schedule.paragraph2: Notes are documented within 24 hours in a short summary so everyone sees the tasks and deadlines clearly.

checklist.heading: Visual checklist
checklist.paragraph1: The second block reviews visual consistency—palette, light direction, and material storytelling under three headings. We assign owners for missing items with quick turnarounds.
checklist.paragraph2: This keeps every deck speaking the same language even when multiple team members contribute.

archive.heading: Archiving and sharing
archive.paragraph1: We store every visual and file on a shared server at the end of the session. Each folder includes a cover sheet with the date, owner, and revision notes.
archive.paragraph2: Maintaining a clear archive gives us ready references for future meetings and avoids duplicate work.

intro.title: Join Presentation-Focused Practice
intro.body: Alpimimarlık is a small, disciplined team managing concept presentations, model shoots, and pre-site communication. We look for curious teammates to strengthen the visual stories prepared in our Galata studio.

atmosphere.body: A close-knit crew brings Galata's rhythm into the studio. The model table, sound system, and photo corner are always ready.

roles.title: Roles We're Hiring
roles.description: Share your portfolio, a short motivation letter, and contact details for the roles below and we respond within a week.

presentationArchitect.title: Presentation Architect
presentationArchitect.body: You'll prepare plans, sections, and atmosphere boards for concept meetings and bring model photography into a catalogue language. Experience with Rhino, Enscape, and Adobe InDesign is expected.

bullets.two: • Ability to write detailed Turkish copy and short English summaries

visualDesigner.title: Visual Communication Designer
visualDesigner.body: We'll co-design posters, social layouts, and covers for launch campaigns. We're looking for someone who preserves our design voice while proposing fresh typography.

studioIntern.title: Studio Intern
studioIntern.body: During summer you will support sketch and model workflows and organise presentation folders before meetings. We'd like to see the narrative voice in your studio projects.

bullets.one: • Third or fourth year architecture student
bullets.two: • Availability for at least three studio days per week

application.title: How to Apply
application.body1: Prepare your portfolio as a PDF of up to 15 pages. In your motivation letter, share the type of presentation you would like to build with the Alpimimarlık team. Include contact details for tutors or collaborators who can provide references.
application.body2: Send your application to kariyer@alpimimarlik.com. We follow up within a week to schedule a meeting or share portfolio feedback.

hero.title: Get in Touch
hero.body: Fill in the form to talk about our campaign-focused presentations or to request access to our archive. We schedule a quick starter session for teams preparing their first presentation.
